thread.title: Durham slips out of Times Higher Education's top 10 Universities in the UK
thread.title_full: Durham slips out of Times Higher Education's top 10 Universities in the UK

author: Hannah Graham
title: Durham slips out of Times Higher Education's top 10 Universities in the UK
text:
Durham slips out of Times Higher Education's top 10 Universities in the UK 05:00, 22 Sep 2016 In World University rankings, Durham has clung on to a place in the top 100 but dropped 26 places, while Newcastle rose to 190th place Share Get daily news by email Durham University 
Durham University has slipped out of the UK’s top 10 this year, as the Times Higher Education (THE) world university rankings are released. 
The 184-year-old institution is now ranked 12th best in the UK, with the University of Warwick snapping up its previous place at number 10. 
On the world stage, Durham has kept its place in the top 100, but slid down the table. 
It now sits at joint 96th, down from 70th in 2015/16. 
Professor Stuart Corbridge, vice-chancellor and Warden at Durham University, said: “The latest Times Higher Education World University Rankings are one of a number of higher education league tables published each year. We are proud to be consistently ranked as a world top 100 university. 
“Overall Durham is performing extremely well globally and is placed as the 12th highest UK university out of 91 UK universities in total in the global list of almost a thousand. 
“In addition, in national league tables we are also consistently ranked as one of the top universities in the UK and top in North East England. 
“Our strategy is to build on our position and make sure we are amongst the best in world for research, education and the wider student experience.” Newcastle University 
Professor Chris Brink, Vice Chancellor of Newcastle University , welcomed the rating boost. 
He added: “It is particularly encouraging that this latest ranking recognises Newcastle’s strengths in research citations and also in our International Outlook which assesses the global nature of our staff and student community and the links we have with global partners.” 
The University of Oxford was named the best in the world, with two other UK institutions — Cambridge and Imperial College London — making the top ten. 
With 88 universities in the top 800, up from 78 last year, the UK is second only to the US for the number institutions in the world’s best 800. 
But as the rankings were released, higher education experts warned that the vote to leave the European Union could pose a “big threat” to higher education in the UK, as it may make it more difficult for academics from working with colleagues on the continent. 
And there are fears Brexit might also discourage overseas students from applying to British universities. 
Phil Baty, editor of the THE world university rankings, said: “The UK must ensure that it limits the damage to academics, students, universities and science during its Brexit negotiations to ensure that the UK remains one of the world leaders in higher education.”
